title: Understanding Ovarian Cysts
subtitle: What they are, how they're diagnosed, and what to expect

content.value:
Ovarian cysts are fluid-filled sacs that develop in or on the ovaries. They are common, especially in people who have not yet gone through menopause.

Many cysts form as part of the normal menstrual cycle (called functional cysts).

items: Many cause no symptoms and go away on their own
Some cysts can grow larger, cause pain, or need monitoring

content.title: Important Note
content.description: Ovarian cysts are less common after menopause. While most are still benign, cysts found after menopause are usually investigated more carefully to rule out any serious causes.

content.value: Seek medical advice if you experience:

items.text: Persistent bloating, abdominal swelling, or pelvic pressure
Needing to urinate more often or difficulty emptying your bladder
Pelvic pain that is ongoing or worsening
Unusual vaginal bleeding, especially after menopause or between periods

content.description: These symptoms can be linked to ovarian cysts or other conditions and should be assessed.

content.value: There are several types of ovarian cysts, ranging from harmless to those requiring treatment.

items.title: Functional Cysts (Usually harmless)
items.content:
**Follicular cysts** - Form when a follicle does not release an egg and continues to grow. Most go away on their own within 1–3 months.

**Corpus luteum cysts** - Form after an egg is released and the follicle reseals and fills with fluid. These usually resolve naturally.

items.title: Other Benign Cysts
items.content:
**Endometriomas** — Cysts linked to endometriosis, sometimes called “chocolate cysts.

**Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas)** — Develop from early cells that can form different tissue types. Usually benign.

**Cystadenomas** — Fluid-filled cysts that develop from ovarian tissue and can grow large.

**Polycystic ovaries (PCOS)** — PCOS involves multiple small follicles seen on scan. These are not true cysts but part of a hormonal condition.

content.value: Less Common but Important Types Include:

items.title: Malignant (cancerous) tumours
items.content: Most ovarian cysts are not cancer. However, cysts found after menopause or with concerning features need careful assessment.

content.title: Many cysts cause no symptoms
content.description: Larger or complicated cysts may cause:

items.title: Common Symptoms
items.description:
Bloating, abdominal swelling, or pressure

Pelvic pain (dull or sharp, may come and go)

Pain during periods or sex

Sudden severe pain with nausea or vomiting (possible ovarian torsion)

Sudden sharp pain if a cyst ruptures

items.title: Less Common Symptoms
items.description:
Lower back or thigh ache

Feeling unable to fully empty the bladder or bowel

Needing to urinate more often

items.title: Breast tenderness & unexplained weight gain
items.description: These are not typical ovarian cyst symptoms and may relate to hormonal changes or other conditions.

items.title: Unusual vaginal bleeding
items.description: Not a classic cyst symptom and should always be checked to rule out other causes.

content.title: When to seek help urgently
content.description: Seek urgent care if you have sudden severe abdominal pain, especially with fever, vomiting, dizziness, or fainting.

content.value: Certain factors can make ovarian cysts more likely:

items.text: Ovulation-inducing fertility treatments – medicines that stimulate ovulation can increase the chance of functional cysts
Endometriosis – linked to endometriomas (a type of cyst)
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) – involves multiple small follicles due to hormone imbalance
Previous ovarian cysts – increases the chance of future cysts
Being of reproductive age – cysts are more common before menopause

content.value: Most ovarian cysts do not affect your ability to get pregnant.

items.text: Most ovarian cysts do not affect fertility
Some underlying conditions linked to cysts, such as PCOS or endometriosis, can affect fertility
Cysts found during pregnancy are often harmless, but larger or symptomatic cysts may need monitoring and occasionally treatment

content.title: Important Note
content.description: If you're trying to conceive and have concerns about ovarian cysts, speak to your doctor.

steps: Pelvic examination – may detect tenderness or a mass, though small cysts may not be felt
Ultrasound scan – the main test used to confirm and assess a cyst
Blood tests – may check hormone levels or markers such as CA-125 in certain situations (mainly after menopause or if features are concerning)
MRI scan – sometimes used if ultrasound findings are unclear

content.value: Many simple cysts are monitored over time to see if they reduce in size or resolve on their own.

content.title: Self-Care Tips
content.description:
Track your symptoms (pain, bloating, period changes)

Rest and manage activity levels if you feel discomfort

Seek medical advice if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop

content.title: When is surgery needed?
content.description: Surgery may be considered if a cyst is large, causing significant symptoms, does not go away, or has features that need further assessment.

items.title: Laparoscopy
items.description:
Keyhole surgery using small cuts in the abdomen.

Often used for smaller or uncomplicated cysts

Usually involves removing the cyst while preserving the ovary where possible

Recovery time is generally shorter

items.title: Laparotomy
items.description:
Open surgery through a larger abdominal cut.

May be used for very large cysts or when cancer cannot be ruled out

Allows the surgeon to assess the area more thoroughly

content.title: Important Note
content.description: The type of surgery depends on the cyst’s size, appearance on scans, symptoms, and your overall health. Your specialist will discuss the benefits and risks before any procedure.
